info.game_comments:
2016 Teachers Tournament final game 2.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Seville oranges are big in making this preserve, a word from the Portuguese

(3, 1).clue: His "Advice to a Young Tradesman": "Remember that" this "is Money"

(4, 1).clue: Ghostly sightings at Hampton Court Palace include one of Catherine Howard, wife of this monarch who had her executed

(5, 1).clue: Money proved superior to this system of swapping goods, as it was hard walking around with a cow or a sack of pears

(6, 1).clue: Great Sacandaga Lake in this state helps regulate the flow of the Hudson

(1, 2).clue: The outside of an orange is the peel; this 4-letter term also starting with "P" is the white substance between the peel & flesh

(3, 2).clue: "In this world nothing can be... certain, except" these 2 things

(4, 2).clue: A giant one of these 5-pointed stars showed up on a lakeside during a Google Earth map survey over Kazakhstan

(5, 2).clue: In 1797 Charles Newbold patented a cast-iron one--better than wood, but farmers worried it would poison the soil

(6, 2).clue: Great Lake is the name of one of the largest lakes in this Australian island state

(1, 3).clue: If I may be sanguine, Sicily is a major producer of this sweet-tart dessert orange

(3, 3).clue: "There never was a good war or" this

(4, 3).clue: Using sonar, even deeper parts of this largest freshwater lake in Britain have been found; make room for plesiosaurs!

(5, 3).clue: During the 17th c. this scientific instrument was improved by making it reflecting, starting with Zucchi's circa 1616

(6, 3).clue: In Utah it receives the Jordan & Weber Rivers

(1, 4).clue: Milk, water, sugar, vanilla, ice cubes & of course, frozen O.J. are in food.com's recipe for this other "O.J."

(3, 4).clue: These "and visitors stink in three days"

(4, 4).clue: In the Southwest there've been reports of livestock being killed by this cryptid creature, Spanish for "goat sucker"

(5, 4).clue: This method of printing, whose elements are seen here, was long superior in China with its pictorial writing

(6, 4).clue: Great Bitter Lake is a marshy lake in Egypt that forms part of this manmade waterway

(1, 5).clue: Loose-skinned oranges like the Clementine are this kind of orange, also the name of a language

(3, 5).clue: From this game "we may learn... foresight... circumspection... caution... and... the habit of not being discouraged"

(4, 5).clue: In Victorian times loved ones were often immortalized in death photos called these, Latin for "remember that you must die"

(5, 5).clue: In a slogan at the start of the Iraq War in 2003, U.S. air superiority was to instill these paired feelings in Iraqis

(6, 5).clue: The fourth-largest lake in North America, it was named for the large mammals that inhabited its shores

(1, 1).clue: Born in 1577 and named for two saints, he's the Flemish master seen here in a self-portrait

(2, 1).clue: Harry Obst helped 7 presidents communicate with German leaders & wrote the book "White House" this job

(3, 1).clue: The title character in Ralph Ellison's "Invisible Man" moves from the Deep South to this New York City district

(4, 1).clue: Yale's Peabody Museum features "The Great Hall of" these mighty extinct creatures

(5, 1).clue: It means pertaining to the tongue

(1, 2).clue: His home & gardens in Giverny have been open to the public since 1980

(2, 2).clue: Sherlock Holmes often hears of new developments in a case via this, aka "the Victorian Internet"

(3, 2).clue: In 1998 author Gloria Naylor revisited this title "Place", this time giving "The Men" a chance to be heard from

(4, 2).clue: Jann Wenner of Rolling Stone helped to establish this in Cleveland in 1983
(4, 2).correct response: the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame

(5, 2).clue: A pointy part of a fishhook, or a pointedly unpleasant remark

(1, 3).clue: He hadn't yet invented Pointillism when he did the painting seen here, his first large-scale work

(2, 3).clue: On film Ringo Starr played Atouk, this title type of "man", whose language included ool ("food") & haraka ("fire")

(3, 3).clue: Walter Mosley's "Devil in a Blue Dress" saw the 1st appearance of this "effortless" detective in 1940s Los Angeles

(4, 3).clue: Royal Albert Hall had a record crowd of 9,000 in 1906 when folks listened to one of these newfangled inventions

(5, 3).clue: A cabbie with an empty taxi may go to the airport to make this

(1, 4).clue: You can see his "Jane Avril Leaving the Moulin Rouge" at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford

(2, 4).clue: From March to May of 1932, the Lindbergh family received 13 of these criminal communications

(3, 4).clue: Anthony is the middle name of this award-winning author who released her 11th novel, "God Help the Child", in 2015

(4, 4).clue: The Galerie des Glaces, or Hall of Mirrors, is quite a site at this onetime royal residence

(5, 4).clue: It's the list of all the available players you can use in your team's lineup

(1, 5).clue: The painting seen here is one of eight scenes that make up this Brit's "A Rake's Progress"

(2, 5).clue: You won't be able to make out the message if there's too low an S/N ratio, S/N standing for this

(3, 5).clue: Chester Himes explored racism in this book whose 6-word title is in the rhyme "Eeny-Meeny-Miney-Mo"
(3, 5).correct response: If He Hollers Let Him Go

(4, 5).clue: The attempted coup d'etat known by this name began at the Burgerbraukeller on Nov. 8, 1923

(5, 5).clue: Used to help eliminate distortion, it's the type of map projection seen here

(0, 0).clue: He was awarded a DFC in WWII for a combat mission as pilot of the B-24 bomber he named the "Dakota Queen"
